g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
of the particles released during concrete cutting are respirable airborne particles composed of
quartz [
]. A signiﬁcant portion of the concentrations of respirable airborne particles (numbers
of particles in certain air volume) could be ultraﬁne particles including particles of <100 nmsizes [
Based on the US National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) deﬁnition of nano dimensions [
and ASTME2456-06 standard [
], we may consider these <100 nmparticles as nanoparticles as a sub
category of ultraﬁne particles. Different industrial work processes may produce particles that have
dimensions in the nanometer size range, which are often referred to as ultraﬁne particles [
]. We will
use the term ultraﬁne particles in this article to avoid any confusion. A previous laboratory-based
study conducted by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) researchers
demonstrated the potential generation of nanoparticles and other particles of 3–500 nmsizes during
simulated grinding activity [
]. These observations warrant further study on exposure assessment of
ultraﬁne particle in construction jobsites because, according to the March 2018 U.S. Bureau of Labor
Statistics, approximately 7.15 million workers are employed in the U.S. construction industry [
Ultraﬁne particles are respirable deeper into our alveoli, beyond our body’s natural respiratory
cleaning mechanisms such as cilia and mucous membranes, and are likely to be retained in the lower
airways [
]. These particles have the potential to cause serious diseases, such as respiratory symptoms,
lung cancer, and silicosis, depending on the components of the particles [
]. Respirable ﬁne and
ultraﬁne particles at construction sites may carry crystalline and amorphous silica and may stimulate
and suppress the immune system and cause injury to cells of several organs [
]. The ultraﬁne
particles are thought to have different toxic effects depending on their surface characteristics [
Recent studies suggest that the high surface area of silica and TiO
nanoparticles may aggravate airway
inﬂammation and may have adverse effects on human health [
]. On these premises, adequate
respiratory protection by personal protective equipment like ﬁltering facepiece respirators is relevant
across varying construction tasks performed by construction workers.
The exposure levels of ultraﬁne particles through the above-described construction tasks are
largely unknown, and previous studies mostly focused on coarse airborne particles, PM
, and PM
(particles that have aerodynamic diameters less than or equal to 10.0
µ
mand 2.5
µ
m, respectively) [
Understanding the exposure levels and penetration levels of ultraﬁne particles through N95 masks,
however, are critically important because recent laboratory studies have demonstrated cytotoxicity
of silica nanoparticles on lung epithelial cells [
]. Furthermore, because nanoparticles have a much
greater surface area [
], they can adsorb airborne NO
, SO
, and other pollutants [
] released from
machines on construction jobsites.
In general, it is believed that the dust generated during mechanical processes on construction
jobsites is mostly coarse particles (>1
µ
m) formed through construction tasks described above, and this
belief is in line with ﬁndings fromprevious studies [
]. Consequently, little attention has been paid
to the ultraﬁne particles generated fromthese tasks and their exposure levels. These data are, however,
essential because recent laboratory studies have suggested adverse health effects of ultraﬁne and ﬁne
particles, as described above.
Concrete grinding and cutting are very dusty jobs in the construction industry, which may pose a
severe health risk to masons [
]. Masonry bricks, blocks, and concrete slabs may contain signiﬁcant
amounts of crystalline silica, which can be released into the workers’ breathing zone when these
materials are dry-cut [
]. The exposure levels are often above [
] the Occupational Safety and
Health Administration’s (OSHA) recently revised Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) for silica, which
is 50
µ
g/m
], and Threshold Limit Values (TLV) of the American Conference of Government
Industrial Hygienist (ACGIH) for crystalline silica, which is 25
µ
g/m
for time-weighted average
(TWA) of a 8 h work shift [
]. Therefore, continuous chronic exposure to these hazardous dust levels
can lead to the development of silicosis among workers.
Building construction in the United States involves numerous wooden structures, which are
routinely used in framing walls, ﬂoors, stairs, and landings in new building construction [
Numerous workers are involved in timber-based construction and wood dust is one of their most
